Learning disabilities and visual-motor skills; comparing assessment from a hapto-virtual reality tool and Bender-Gestalt test

Learning disabilities and visual-motor skills; comparing assessment from a hapto-virtual reality tool and Bender-Gestalt test

  • Brahim Chebbi1,
  • Stéphane Bouchard2,
  • Krystel Cimon-Lambert1 &
  • Jessica Carmichael1 

Virtual Reality volume 18, pages49–60(2014)Cite this article

  • 758 Accesses

  • 3 Citations

  • 1 Altmetric

Abstract

Previous investigations conducted on post-secondary adult students with learning disabilities (LD) suggest that deficits in visual-motor skills contribute to difficulties in written expression which impact academic achievement. Intervention strategies for individuals with LD include assistive computer-based technologies (ATs) to compensate for or maximize performance. However, research fails to assess the impact of ATs on performance, learning, and motivation of students with LD. Also, one of the limitations of ATs is that they cannot be used for assessment and training and there are very few methods to assess or train visual-motor skills in this population. The present study explores the usefulness of a hapto-visual virtual reality motor skills assessment (MSA) device for visual-motor functioning in adults with and without LD. This is a preliminary step of developing an intervention to improve impaired visual-motor skills in adults with LD. A sample of 22 male and female university students with and without LD had their visual-motor skills pretested using a standard paper-and-pencil Bender-Gestalt (BG) test and were compared according to their performance on the MSA tool. We hypothesized that our LD participants’ performance would be significantly lower than our control participants on the VR task in terms of number of errors and speed. Results showed that participants without LD performed better and more rapidly on the VR task than participants with LD. There were no correlations between the BG and MSA performance. We did not find significant differences between the groups on the Bender-Gestalt scores, previous experience with video game, arousal, and mood. Our results suggest that a novel 3D virtual reality tool such as the MSA can potentially discriminate motor function of people with and without LD; however, the difference between both may also be due to a lack of problem-solving ability in LD.

Introduction

Learning disabilities prevalence rates in adults are estimated to be about 3–8 % in English-speaking countries (Vogel and Holt 2003). In Canada, it is estimated that adults represent at least three percent of all individuals diagnosed with a learning disability (LD) every year (Human Resources and Skills Development Canada 2006). In North America, adults with LD also represent 36–60 % of all students with disabilities enrolled in post-secondary education (Day and Edwards 1996; Martinez-Marrero and Estrada-Hernandez 2008; Orr and Hammig 2009; The Ontario Human Rights Commission 2002; Voytecki et al. 2009). LD is a disorder characterized by an academic under-achievement in comparison with average or above average intellectual functioning (APA 2000). Although the etiology of LD is not yet known, research suggests that symptoms originate from impairments in one or more processes related to perception, attention, cognitions, executive function, and memory (Dumas and Nilsen 2003; Durand 2005; Estil et al. 2003; Getchell et al. 2005; Martinez-Marrero and Estrada-Hernandez 2008), which may explain why research has demonstrated that poor visual-motor skills (Getchell et al. 2005), difficulties in visual discrimination tasks (Dumas and Nilsen 2003), and in fine and gross motor tasks (Hill 1998; Owen and McKinlay 1997) have been found in children with LD compared to children without. Visual-motor skills (or visual-motor integration or coordination) reflect the degree to which visual perception and finger–hand movements are well coordinated (Beery and Beery 2006). Motor skills are defined in terms of the ability to manipulate body parts and objects physically (Brannigan and Decker 2003; Brown et al. 2009).

Although there are much less research investigations conducted on adults with LD compared to those focusing on children, the findings of these investigations suggest very few differences between these groups in relation to the diagnostic features of intelligence, achievement, perceptual, cognitive, and visual-motor functions (McCue et al. 1986). Because visual-motor skills are involved in many aspects of learning such as writing, limitations in these skills impact academic achievement. Indeed, difficulties in written expression are the most commonly reported problems for post-secondary students (Day and Edwards 1996; Martinez-Marrero and Estrada-Hernandez 2008), supporting the contention that visual-motor challenges in adults would reflect the persistence of difficulties that originate in childhood (Kirby et al. 2008). However, some researchers refute the idea of visual-motor deficits persistence. For example, Sobotka et al. (1977) found a significant difference between dyslexics and control children on the Bender-Gestalt visual-motor assessment scale for 7-year-old, but not for 9-, 11- or 13-year-old children. Whether or not visual-motor difficulties originate from childhood, research shows that visual-motor skills impairments are present in at least a proportion of adults with LD. For example, Ramus et al. (2003) found that four out of sixteen adults with dyslexia showed motor deficits. Investigations using motor reduced tests such as the Test of Visual-Perceptual Skills (Hung et al. 1987) and visual-motor integration tests such as the Bender-Gestalt (Brannigan and Decker 2003) report scores that are lower in adults with LD compared to control participants. Also, others have found that adults with LD perform significantly worse than controls on motor-specific tactile discrimination tasks (Grant et al. 1999; Stoodley et al. 2000). Typically, visual-motor abilities are measured through the use of general paper-and-pencil methods; however, new intervention strategies for individuals with LD include computer-based technologies to compensate for or maximize performance, but these strategies involve very little writing or skills measured by classical tests (Tremblay et al. 2011). Also, very few methods exist for the measurement of visual-motor skills for adults with LDs.

Classical interventions for children and adults diagnosed with LDs include extended test-taking time, modified assignment expectations, note-taking services, and assistive technologies (AT) such as print magnification systems, enlarged computer keyboards, paper-based computer pen and mouse emulators; optical character recognition and speech output devices (Raskind 1993; Raskind and Higgins 1998; Orr and Hammig 2009). Although ATs benefit students in several ways (e.g., increasing motivation), existing literature failed to examine the effect of AT on academic achievement of students with LD (see Tremblay et al. 2011 for a review). Also, interventions using AT have some limitations. First, these interventions are based on a compensatory approach which aims at circumventing the student’s specific deficit rather than taking a remedial approach, which consists in improving specific areas of difficulties that can be viewed as more effective as it can provide the student with strategies that can be generalized to different areas of difficulties (Brown 2008; Day and Edwards 1996; Martinez-Marrero and Estrada-Hernandez 2008). Second, the use of some of these ATs requires visual-motor and visual-spatial skills that are impaired in some students with LD (MacArthur 1998; Raskind 1993; Raskind and Higgins 1998) and therefore requires training for these students to really benefit from these tools (Draffan et al. 2007). Third, ATs do not provide feedback on performance to the user and cannot be used for assessment and training (Tremblay et al. 2011). Fourth, motor-specific ATs often need to be customized to fit the specific needs or deficits of an individual with an LD (Bahr et al. 1996).

VR technologies offer an interesting new type of intervention for post-secondary student with visual-motor skills deficit as they enable educators and therapists to measure a wide range of human movements by varying controlled stimuli to be presented to the users, as well as providing systematic feedback on their performance (Cromby et al. 1996; Holden 2005; Riva 2003; Wille et al. 2009). Thus, VR can be used as both an assessment and a training tool.

By reviewing the literature, Tremblay et al. (2011) found numerous research findings suggesting that visual-motor skills among different populations of adults with neurological, psychological, or physical impairments can be improved by training in VR environments. For normal adult participants, spatial navigation tasks in VR produce significant improvements in motor skills (Regian and Shebilske 1992). Video game training increases visual-spatial attention capacity within the areas of video game playing (Green and Bavelier 2003). More video game experience is associated with better performance on 3D visual-motor navigation tasks among normal adult college students (Richardson and Collaer 2011). Also, there is an increasing number of research findings showing that improvement in motor skills acquired through VR training can be transferred and generalized to real-world environments (Chebbi et al. 2009; Goncharenko et al. 2006; Holden 2005; Klatzky et al. 2003).

We found very few investigations utilizing VR to measure, assess, or train visual-motor skills among adults with LD. These investigations showed significant improvements in VR training of visual-motor skills, which was ported to real-life environments (Brooks et al. 2002; Rose et al. 2000). The limitation of these studies is that they do not have control groups.

Regardless of the presence of LD, several factors influence motor skill performance, including gender, arousal, caffeine consumption, sleep deprivation, and fatigue. First, research findings suggest gender dependence. Although the opposite is true for the general population (Duran and Fisher 1996; Woodard and Surburg 1997), some researchers studying adults with LD have indicated that females tend to perform better on traditional visual-motor measures than males. For example, females with LD have been found to display better writing skills, finger dexterity, speed, and accuracy of finger tapping than males (Vogel 1990). Similarly, Ramus et al. (2003) found that dyslexic males were more impaired than their female counterparts in the motor skills assessment.

Second, arousal, or the level of alertness, has an impact on different cognitive processes including visual-motor performance. For example, negative emotion such as anxiety narrows attention and influences visual and auditory perception as well as reaction time (for a review see Oatley et al. 2006). On the opposite, relaxation techniques reducing arousal improve visual-motor skills as demonstrated by Carter and Russell’s experimental study (Carter and Russell 1985) comparing primary school boys with LD to control participants.

Third, it is also well documented that experimentally induced arousal by means of caffeine consumption moderates performance, showing positive effects at low to moderate dosage, but negative effects at dosages exceeding 500 mg (Beck 2004; Frewer and Lader 1991). Caffeine consumption affects different aspects of cognitive function such as attention, memory, and learning as well as motor performance (Demojà et al. 1985; Lieberman et al. 2002; Smith et al. 2005). However, chronic consumption of caffeine does not appear to have an effect on cognitive and motor performance (Judelson et al. 2005). Fourth, sleep deprivation and fatigue adversely affect performance in reaction time, learning and memory, vigilance, and motor tasks (Dawson and Reid 1997; Jung et al. 2011; Lieberman et al. 2002; Smith et al. 2005).

As the use of ATs is now well implemented in post-secondary institutions, it is important to understand its impact on post-secondary students with LD in terms of learning, motivation, and performance. To achieve this goal, we must first begin by developing new methods to assess student basic visual-motor abilities to operate these tools, which is what we intended to do in the present study. Information gained by such assessment will lead us to the next step of developing and testing an intervention to improve impaired visual-motor skills in adults.

With the results of this review of the literature in mind, the main objective of the current study is to test the usefulness of a hapto-visual virtual reality system (Bazinet et al. 2011) to assess visual-motor functioning of adults with and without LD. This system permits testing of motor skills since it allows manipulation of objects in a 3D environment and adds tactile sensation to computer tasks, which are traditionally visual (Adamovich et al. 2009).

By taking into account pretest visual-motor paper-and-pencil assessment, arousal, and previous experience with video games, we postulate that our LD participants’ performance would be significantly lower than our control participants on the VR task. More specifically, we expect that participants with LD will commit more errors while manipulating virtual objects and will take more time to successfully complete the tasks compared to participants without LD.

Method

Participants

Twenty-two university students participated in the study. Half of the participants (N = 11) were recruited through our University Accessibility Services therapists who agreed to present and advertise this study to students previously diagnosed with a LD (dyslexia, with or without a learning disability specific to writing, oral communication, or mathematics) from a licensed psychologist.Footnote 1 Participants with a comorbid diagnosis of mood disorders or psychosis were excluded. Participants with a LD were paired with 11 control participants (non-LD; NLD) according to their age (M = 23 years, ET = 3.8) and gender (6 males and 16 females). Participating students were recruited from different undergraduate programs, and control participants were recruited from the same classrooms. Both groups received a class bonus mark for participation.

Procedure

At first, the participants were administered questionnaires inquiring about their previous experience with video games, arousal, and mood and had their visual-motor skills assessed before being instructed on how to use the virtual reality tool. Participants had a 90-s practice run before the real test on the virtual reality program, which lasts 15 min. The length of the period was determined by a pretest we conducted in a small group of students. At the end of the practice session, both groups showed the same performance; the average number of organs removed were, respectively, .73 (SD = .90) for NLD and .81 (SD = .60) for LD [F(1,20) = .08, p = .78, η 2 = 004], whereas the number of errors were, respectively, 6.20 (SD = 8.20) for NLD and 4.82 (SD = 6.80) for LD [F(1,20) = .2, p = .68, η 2 = .009]. Therefore, all participants started testing at the same level. Each student was informed not to consume any caffeine beverages 1 h prior to their participation. Each session took approximately 60 min to complete.

Measures and apparatus

Pretest measures

Visual-motor skills

Performance in our motor skill virtual tool assessment is difficult to compare with a real-life situation (e.g., manipulating real-life objects) because the latter does not permit precise assessment like those provided by computer programs. Therefore, we choose to assess our participants’ visual-motor skills by using the Bender Visual-Motor Gestalt test 2nd Ed (Brannigan and Decker 2003), one of the most widely used paper-and-pencil standardized tests with norms for individuals from ages 4 to 85 (Tremblay et al. 2011). The BG provides standard scores (M = 100, SD = 15), defined as scores converted to a standard deviation unit permitting to compare an examinee’s position relative to the mean in a normative sample (Anastasi and Urbina 1997). The test requires the participants to accurately relate visual stimuli to motor responses by copying age appropriate drawings that are shown one at a time on cards (Copy Scale). A second scale (Recall) requires the participant to recall and copy as accurately as they can as many of the designs the administrator had just shown them. The recall task provides a brief assessment of memory and how well the participant encodes, stores, and retrieves information, which can be influenced by motor and perceptual problems (Brannigan and Decker 2003). Performances are quantified by using the standardized and extensively studied Koppitz Developmental Scoring System-2, which has good psychometric properties and is considered a good screening tool for normal versus impaired visual-motor integrative abilities (Reynolds 2008).

Experience with computers

Previous experience with computers and video games was measured by two questions. Participants were asked how much experience they have using video games, computer games, virtual reality games, or computer programs according to the following scale: (1) = not at all, (3) = average amount, to (5) = a lot. Participants were also asked to indicate the number of years of experience they have using video or computer games. Similarly to most video games, our tool is goal directed. These questions are used as indicators of both general experience with video games and drive for achievement, which was found to affect enjoyment with video game and mood (Song et al. 2013).

Arousal and mood

Pretest levels of arousal can affect attention and cognitive processes. These factors are experimental artifacts that could prevent the verification of the main hypothesis, which predicts a lower performance in participants with LD compared to participants without LD. We measured participants’ arousal by asking them about the amount of sleep in hours/minutes they had during the last week and the night before the experiment, and the number of caffeinated beverages (number of 250 ml cups) they consumed the day of their participation. Mood was measured using six visual analog scales which require the participant to indicate a position along a continuous line between two ends: (1) passive/active (2) calm/frustrated (3) good/bad (4) happy/sad (5) sedated/aroused, and (6) calm/anxious.

Apparatus: motor skill assessment virtual reality device

The motor skills assessment (MSA) virtual reality device (Bazinet et al. 2011) is a virtual reality system similar to the classic board game “Operations” and that makes use of 3D computer graphics and simulates the sensation of touch through the use of a haptic device. It uses a Phantom Omni haptic device from Sensables Technologies and runs on a Lenovo desktop computer with 3 GHz Core 2 duo CPU and 2 Gb of RAM. The application was developed using C++, OpenGL, and the Open Haptics API. The system is shown in Fig. 1; the user of this MSA virtual reality device must rely on his or her visual-motor skills and attention ability to remove organs from a cartoonish human body and place them on a tray, in an interactive, simulated virtual environment. The organs of the virtual human body replicate the relative sizes of real organs, that is, larger organs were programmed to be heavier—thus, perceived as heavier—than small ones. To achieve this, higher levels of resistance while moving the joystick were paired with increasing weight, which emulates an increasing sensation of effort when the participant moved the stylus of the haptic device.

The participants were instructed to carefully remove each organ from the “patient” represented on the computer screen by using the virtual reality device and to take the least amount of time possible, while doing their best not to touch the organ’s enclosures. Feedback during performance was provided by vibration of the hand tool paired with an auditory signal each time the organ touched the enclosure. Accumulation of collisions (errors) was associated with indication that the “patient’s” health decreased. With each organ successfully removed, the participant gained points.

A 90-s practice preceded the test which consisted of three 300 s trials, each increasing by their levels of difficulty. In level one (T1 = Low), organs were light and smaller than the enclosure. In level two (T2 = Moderate), organs were slightly heavier and larger than organs in level one but still smaller than the enclosures, whereas the third and final level (T3 = High) had heavier and larger organs with small clearance from the enclosures. If the participants successfully removed all the organs before the end of a trial, the exact performance time was recorded. Otherwise, the trial ended when the 300 s elapsed and the number of organs removed was recorded. Performance was assessed by (1) the ratio of the number of organs removed to the number of collisions (performance score) and (2) the ratio of the performance to the time to complete the task (speed score) through the three levels of difficulty (T1, T2, and T3).

Results

Relationships between LD status and visual-motor skills assessment

We performed a series of analyses of variances (ANOVA) to verify whether there were differences between our LD and NLD participants on the standard test of visual-motor skills. Descriptive statistics are shown in Table 1. We did not find significant differences between the groups on BG copy standard scores, F(1,20) = 2.56, p = .17, η 2 = .09, or BG recall standard scores, F(1,20) = .02, p = .49, η 2 = .02, although the copy phase standard scores of participants without LD were higher than those of the participants with LD. Mean standard scores on the copy and the recall phases of our participants with LD (respectively, 109 and 113) and without LD (respectively, 117 and 112) are higher than those reported by Brannigan and Decker’s (2003) validation study in which it was found that scores in the samples representing the different types of LD ranged from 89 to 92 for the copy phase and from 92 to 93 for the recall phase compared to 103–104 and 102–103 for the copy and recall phases, respectively, among their control participants.

Relationships between LD status, experience, mood, and arousal

We performed a series of univariate analyses of variances (ANOVA) to verify whether there were any difference between our LD and NLD participants in the pretest measures of experience with video games, arousal, and mood. Descriptive statistics are shown in Table 1. We did not find any significant differences between LD and NLD participants on reported experience with video/computer games, F(1,20) = .13, p = .72, η 2 = .006, the number of years of using video or computer games, F(1,20) = 3.9, p = 06, η 2 = .17, the amount of sleep during the last week, F(1,20) = .65, p = .43, η 2 = .03, and the night before the experiment, F(1,20) = .002, p = .96, η 2 = .000, the number of caffeinated beverages they had consumed, F(1,20) = 2.8, p = .11, η 2 = .12, or on pretest measures of mood, that is, passive/active, F(1,20) = .001, p = .98, η 2 = .000, calm/frustrated, F(1,20) = .88, p = .60, η 2 = .014, good/bad, F(1,20) = .34, p = .57, η 2 = .017, happy/sad, F(1,20) = .29, p = .59, η 2 = .015, sedated/aroused, F(1,20) = 2.8, p = .11, η 2 = .12., and calm/anxious, F(1,20) = .28, p = .60, η 2 = .014.

Association between pretest measures and MSA performance and speed scores

We conducted Pearson product-moment correlation analyses to verify the hypothesis of association between pretest measures of Bender-Gestalt visual-motor skills assessment, previous experience with computer and video games, arousal, and mood with MSA performance or speed scores. The results are shown in Table 2.

First, we did not find any significant relationship between the BG copy standard scores, or the BG recall standard scores with the performance or speed scores. However, the results showed significant correlations between the BG scales and other predictors. First, it was found that higher BG copy standard scores were associated with lower reported experience with video games, r = −.56, p < .01, and fewer years of experience with games, r = −.71, p < .001. Similarly, higher BG recall standard scores were associated with lower reported experience with video games r = −.57, p < .01, and fewer years of experience with games, r = −.52, p < .01. We did not find any significant association between reported experience and number of years playing games with MSA performance or speed scores. Second, higher MSA performance scores in T2, r = .59, p < .01, MSA speed scores in T1, r = .56, p < .01, and T2, r = .59, p < .01, were associated with higher amount of caffeinated beverages consumed. No significant associations between the amounts of consumed caffeine with BG standard scores were found. Third, MSA performance scores in T3, r = −.45, p < .05, and BG recall standard scores, r = −.56, p < .01, were significantly and negatively associated with bad/good pretest mood. BG copy standard scores, r = −.47, p < .05, were significantly and negatively associated with sedated/aroused pretest mood, whereas BG recall standard scores, r = −.47, p < .05, were significantly and negatively associated with sad/happy pretest mood. Finally, higher reported experience with video games was positively associated with number of years of experience with games, r = .53, p = .01, and with pretest measures of sad/happy mood, r = .46, p < .05.

Comparisons between LD and NLD participants on MSA performance and speed scores

We performed a series of profile analyses of repeated measures (Tabachnick and Fidell 2007) on the three levels of performance and speed measures to compare the participants according to their LD/NLD status. First, we found that the profiles for performance, seen in Fig. 2a, deviated significantly from parallelism, F(2,19) = 6.5, p = .009, η 2 = .39, and flatness, F(2,19) = 3.8, p = .04, η 2 = .29. For the levels, no significant differences were found between the groups when scores were averaged over all levels, F(1,20) = 2.8, p = .11, η 2 = .12. Post hoc analyses of simple effect using a Scheffé adjustment procedure showed a significant difference, F(1,20) = 4.9, p = .04, between LD participants (M = .19, SD = .15) and NLD participants (M = .41, SD = .29) on performance scores at T3. We did not find a significant difference in performance scores at T1, F(1,20) = .1, p > .05, or at T2, F(1,20) = 1.7, p > .05, between LD (M = .20, SD = .09 at T1; M = .13, SD = .10 at T2) and NLD participants (M = .22, SD = .25 at T1; M = .52 SD = .99 at T2).

Second, we found that the profiles for speed, seen in Fig. 2b, deviated significantly from parallelism, F(2,19) = 4.7, p = .022, η 2 = .33, and flatness, F(2,19) = 9.4, p = .001, η 2 = .50. For the levels, no significant differences were found between the groups when scores were averaged over all levels, F(1,20) = 1.5, p = .22, η 2 = .07. Post hoc analyses of simple effect using a Scheffé adjustment procedure showed a significant difference, F(1,20) = 5.9, p = .02, between LD participants (M = .07, SD = .06) and NLD participants (M = .17, SD = .12) on speed scores at T3. We did not find a significant difference in speed scores at T1, F(1,20) = .5, p > .05, or at T2, F(1,20) = 1.1, p > .05, between LD (M = .05, SD = .03 at T1; M = .06, SD = .08 at T2) and NLD participants (M = .08, SD = .15 at T1; M = .31, SD = −.79 at T2).

Discussion

The development of new tools is necessary to understand how ATs influence performance, learning and motivation for post-secondary students with LD. The first step required to achieve this goal is to measure the student basic visual-motor abilities in computer-based technologies, which is not achieved by classical paper–pencil tests.

The current study’s objective was to verify the hypothesis that our VR assessment tool can discriminate visual-motor skills of adults with and without LD. In support of our hypothesis, we found significantly different patterns of performance between the groups. Participants without LD showed an increase in their ability to remove organs as well as the speed used to perform this task across the three levels of difficulties. On the other hand, the profile of adults with LD remained relatively flat across the three levels, indicating a smaller learning effect. The average number of organs removed, however, was significantly different between the groups only at the highest level of difficulty. This result suggests that the maximum number of organs (7) may be too small to measure the optimal performance of both groups. Further improvements of our software will take this aspect into consideration to avoid a possible ceiling effect that could prevent discrimination between individuals with and without visual-motor deficits. Since the groups were not significantly different on any of the pretest measures of arousal, previous experience, and were matched according to their age and gender, our results suggest that the difference in performance is associated with the LD/NLD status.

Contrary to our expectations, we found no association between visual-motor skills assessed by the Bender-Gestalt and the MSA task performances. There are several possible explanations for this. First, we did not find significant differences between our groups on Bender-Gestalt visual-motor assessment scale, although the NLD group showed higher scores than the LD group. Our finding seems inconsistent with Brannigan and Decker’s (2003) validation study which also reported lower scores than the ones we obtained on both subscales. However, Brannigan and Decker’s study was conducted on a sample of participants whose age varied between 6 and 19 years, which prevents a fair comparison with our study which involves older participants.

A second explanation of this result is the population of university students we studied. Indeed, as pointed out by Ramus et al. (2003), the problem associated with university students is that they are not likely to represent the population of LD as we can assume they have higher cognitive abilities and have less comorbid conditions, such as visual-motor challenges, and more resources—all factors that permitted them to attain higher education. Also, the population of LD is not homogeneous, and it is estimated that between 30 and 50 % of individuals will present deficiencies in visual-spatial and/or motor skills (Leton et al. 1987; Ramus et al. 2003). We found that standard deviations are larger in our LD group, compared to control, which may reflect this variability in visual-motor skills of different types of learning pathologies. Our sample size was too small to control for this possible bias. Another possible bias explaining the lack of difference between the groups on Bender-Gestalt subscales is self-selection of participants. About 100 participants were contacted. That means only 10 % agreed to participate. It is possible that our volunteers were those who felt more skilled in visual-motor tasks. Also, students with LD with more severe visual-motor deficits may have felt too anxious or threatened by the nature of our study to volunteer.

Although possible, the above-mentioned reasons are not sufficient to explain both the lack of association between the two measures of visual-motor performance and the significant difference between the LD and NLD groups. One reasonable explanation is that our MSA task measured different skills than those measured by the Bender-Gestalt. The main differences between the BG test and our MSA tasks pertain to familiarity with the tasks, their ratio of visual-motor coordination, and the types of sensory systems involved. The Bender-Gestalt test requires handwriting, a familiar 2D task, whereas our MSA task is novel and requires the participants to learn to manipulate our haptic device in 3D. Second, the Bender-Gestalt involved visual perception and memory to correctly reproduce figures. Performance in MSA, in addition to using visual perception, relies on auditory feedback since errors in motor responses are signaled by a sound. Third, tactile information necessary for performance is provided solely from the 2D contact between the participant’s hand holding the pencil and the piece of paper. In MSA, the participant received tactile information in 3D (sensation of depth).

Thus, as motor performance—or errors reproduction—can result from either deficits in perception or in motor skills (Bender 1970), and that MSA task performance feedback is provided mainly through the auditory system, whereas this feedback is visual for the Bender-Gestalt test, it is possible that differences between LD and NLD participants on our MSA are explained by specific deficits in tactile sensory systems in LD participants, rather than poorer hand–eye coordination skills. Some research findings from the literature support this interpretation. First, Leonard et al. (1988) found that perceptual and motor abilities are not interdependent and that errors in visual-motor reproduction tasks are not necessarily attributable to impaired visual perception. Second, research showed that adults with LD have lower tactile acuity than NLD adults (Grant et al. 1999; Stoodley et al. 2000).

Although we did not find group difference with regards to our pretest control variables, we noted that self-report measures of experience with computer and videogames and caffeinated beverage consumption were close to significance (respectively, p = .06 and p = .11) and therefore raise the question of whether they may contribute to explain the groups difference on the MSA performance and speed scores. First, our LD participants reported more years of experience with videogames (10.73) than NLD participants (7.36). This result is not surprising considering the fact that, in the province of Ontario (Canada), children identified with a LD are allowed government’s funding to purchase computers and software as part of the intervention. Thus, we can reasonably assume that our adult LD participants were likely to have had access to a computer (and video games) before their peers. Interestingly, and contrary to what we would have normally expected, LD participants’ longer experience with videogames did not advantage them, since they still showed a poorer performance than NLD participants on the MSA task. Therefore, it is unlikely that this factor could explain our results. Second, we instructed all the participants not to consume any caffeinated beverage 1 h prior to testing. This instruction was repeated several times, and verifications were made by the research assistants before testing (participants failure to respect this guideline will have their testing delayed, which has never happened). Concentration of caffeine varies according to the type of beverage. Highest concentrations are found in coffee (up to 350 mg for a 250 ml cup).The average of caffeinated beverage consumption are of about a half of a cup in the LD group of participants and 1 cup in the NLD participants. The effects of caffeine on performance are positive at low to moderate levels (i.e., concentrations lower than 500 mg, two cups) and counterproductive on performance beyond 500 mg ((Beck 2004; Frewer and Lader 1991). Based on our data, we can assume that more NLD participants have consumed more than 500 mg compared to LD and expect that larger concentrations of caffeine would deteriorate their performance. Since the NLD participants performed better, it does not seem likely that group differences in caffeine consumption could explain our results.

Our last possible explanation of the difference between LD and NLD groups is that performance is not the result of a sensory deficit among LD participants, but rather a lower ability to adapt to exposure to new and discordant sensory motor information. As documented by Welch and Sampanes (2008), VR requires adaptation in learning new ways to coordinate hands and eyes, which requires problem-solving skills, as well as in perceptual recalibration, that is adjusting a sensory system naturally attuned to a system (typically vision) to another one (in our case auditory). Thus, poorer performance of adults with LD would be explained by either less flexibility to adjust to the demands of a new visual-motor task, or less problem-solving skills.

Although our research strengths are (1) to be one among very few investigations using VR and a haptic device to study visual-motor skills in adults with LD, (2) to use a novel perceptual motor task, and (3) to include a control group, our findings must be interpreted on the lights of several limitations. First our sample size is small and is not very likely to represent the heterogeneity of clinical profiles of adults with LD. Second, we studied university students, who are likely to have fewer deficits in general and in motor skills in particular. Investigations studying adults who did not attain post-secondary education are in need. Third, our MSA virtual tool is still in development and we need to continue improving its sensitivity to detect various skills deficits and strengths.

As for assessment and training, our results showed that our MSA virtual tool is promising. First, several of the characteristics of our tool match those of ATs which will permit assessment and training of users’ visual-motor skills in such computer-based environments. These characteristics include (1) the capacity to record and measure visual-motor performance and to provide feedback to the user, (2) the pen-like shape of the haptic device that is held like a regular pen, and (3) the nature of the task that requires visual scanning, attention and motor movement coordination needed by students to complete regular academic task (note taking, web search, and assignment writing on computer). Second, in taking a remedial approach, our MSA tool, with the upcoming modifications suggested by the result of this study, is also intended to be used as a training intervention to improve visual-motor skills in adult with LD or other conditions affecting those skills. The attainment of this goal by training with our tool is expected to be facilitated by (1) its flexibility to involve a different set of motor capacities and sensory modalities, (2) the possibility to easily increase task difficulty and eventually to adjust the task difficulties to each user’s specific needs, and (3) the sensation of touch created through the pen resistance that can eventually permit to transfer the gains in visual-motor skills to real-world environments. The expected results of such intervention are the generalization of improved skills to different areas of difficulties (e.g., use of ATs) and to increase overall academic performance. These effects are expected to be the results of both improved skills and user’s increase confidence in performing a task. Finally, we believe that the numerous advantages of a tool such as our MSA surpass the issue of costs compared to motor-specific ATs technologies which can be quite expensive, when they are customized to fit the specific needs of an individual with an LD (Bahr et al. 1996). Most of the costs of our tool are associated with the haptic device, which can be manipulated without specific adjustment requirements.

Conclusions and recommendation for future research

This exploratory study raises the issue of the paucity of knowledge on visual-motor skills in adults with LD and outlines the importance of developing new tools adapted to measure the impact of technology-based intervention on this population on different aspects of their functioning. This can eventually contribute to improving assessment, diagnostic, intervention, and training.

Our study also raises questions about the effect of haptics in real-life educational settings and the lack of criteria to compare real-life performance with those in VR. The use of haptics to compare individuals with and without LD is very new and, as outlined by San Diego et al. (2012), “there is little published educational research on the uses and impact of haptic simulator” (p. 156). We did not find any study looking at factors predicting performance with haptics (VR vs real life) in individuals with and without LD. We found only few studies in children that look at the effect of haptics on reading and writing skills. The work of Bara et al. (2007) and Bara and Gentaz (2011) in children at risk for academic difficulties showed that the use of haptic exploration coupled with visual-auditory training improves reading and writing skills more than visual-auditory training only. In these studies, the haptic exploration method consisted of presenting children with moveable foam letters (5 mm thick) they could manipulate in addition to learning the same letters’ phonemes. Minogue and Jones (2006) proposed that the effect of real-life haptic exploration is explained by the fact that sensory information from motor manipulation is the primary strategy we use as children to learn and acquire knowledge, as postulated by the classical theories of cognitive development (e.g., Piaget and Inhelder 1969). In the present study, the difference in visual-motor performance found between LD and NLD adult participants, if replicated in future investigations, raises important questions about the possibility of improving academic skills in adults through visual-motor re-education. More research is also needed to investigate the effect of haptic manipulation and training not only on visual-motor skills but also on perception and learning, both in individuals with and without a disability.
